doc.after: The Iberian Peninsula extends from the southernmost extremity at Punta de Tarifa (36Â°00â²15â³N 5Â°36â²37â³Wï»¿ / ï»¿36.00417Â°N 5.61028Â°Wï»¿ / 36.00417; -5.61028) to the northernmost extremity at Estaca de Bares Point (43Â°47â²38â³N 7Â°41â²17â³Wï»¿ / ï»¿43.79389Â°N 7.68806Â°Wï»¿ / 43.79389; -7.68806) over a distance between lines of latitude of about 865Â km (537Â mi) based on a degree length of 111Â km (69Â mi) per degree, and from the westernmost extremity at Cabo da Roca (38Â°46â²51â³N 9Â°29â²54â³Wï»¿ / ï»¿38.78083Â°N 9.49833Â°Wï»¿ / 38.78083; -9.49833) to the easternmost extremity at Cap de Creus (42Â°19â²09â³N 3Â°19â²19â³Eï»¿ / ï»¿42.31917Â°N 3.32194Â°Eï»¿ / 42.31917; 3.32194) over a distance between lines of longitude at 40Â° N latitude of about 1,155Â km (718Â mi) based on an estimated degree length of about 90Â km (56Â mi) for that latitude. The irregular, roughly octagonal shape of the peninsula contained within this spherical quadrangle was compared to an ox-hide by the geographer Strabo.[26]
